awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  Trophic response of marine top predators to decadal changes in food web structure
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. The World Ocean has experienced unprecedented changes over the past century as a result of climate change and the rapid expansion of fisheries. Uncovering the relationships between these coupled environmental stressors and their impact on the feeding behavior of marine top predators (e.g., marine mammals, sea turtles) is critical to our understanding of the functioning, health, resilience, and adaptation of marine ecosystems to environmental disturbance. This project will apply cutting-edge molecular chemistry techniques to archived marine mammal and sea turtle tissues from multiple research collections to examine how foraging strategies and food web structure have changed since the late 19th century in response to changes in climate and fishing. Such information can be used to predict how marine predators and the food webs they control will respond to future ecosystem change in the upcoming century.

The project will use amino acid isotope geochemistry to reconstruct changes in critical parameters of food web architecture (e.g., trophic position, niche breadth, food web baseline) supporting common bottlenose dolphins, harbour porpoises, and loggerhead sea turtles in the western North Atlantic since the late 1800's. Specifically, these data will be used to test three key hypotheses: 1) do decadal shifts in ocean productivity associated with major climatic shifts cause expansion/contraction of marine top predator trophic niches, 2) do declining prey and predator abundances cause marine top predators to compensate by foraging at lower trophic levels or expanding their trophic niches, 3) does increased interspecific competition from the recovery of sympatric species cause trophic niches to contract. This multi-species approach will resolve conflicting accounts of trophic response to environmental change. As part of this project, the fellow will partner with the University of Rhode Island's Inner Space Center (URI-ISC) to develop short educational videos and interactive programming related to ocean science and project activities. Using the URI-ISC's unique telepresence capacity, outreach products and programs will be used to engage the public and next generation of scientists across multiple platforms (e.g., social media, K-12 classrooms). This project will also support diversity in research engagement and training by making use of URI-sponsored programs that broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Human activities have directly and indirectly altered the structure and function of marine systems over the past century in many ways (e.g., climate change, fisheries). Despite decades of study of these stressors and their effects, we still lack understanding of how ecosystem changes resulting from them alter relationships between predators and their prey, particularly for top predators—animals at the top of the food web. This is because historical diet data do not exist over relevant temporal and spatial scales. During my Fellowship, I applied novel molecular isotope tools—compound-specific stable isotope analysis of individual amino acids (CSIA-AA)—to archived specimens of five top predator species that inhabit the Northeast U.S. Shelf to investigate how human activities have reshaped predator-prey relationships over the past century. 

 

Intellectual Merit: To implement this project, I partnered with the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History, North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences, and National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration to build an unprecedented sample set consisting of five top predator species—common bottlenose dolphin, Short-beaked common dolphin, loggerhead sea turtle, Kemp’s ridley sea turtle, Atlantic cod—that spanned the 1880’s to 2010’s. Resulting CSIA-AA data revealed distinct species-and habitat-specific changes in top predator foraging ecology through time that were coincident with shifts in key environmental and ecological conditions (e.g., prey abundance, fishing effort). Ongoing work is using a suite of statistical tools (e.g., time series analysis, general additive models) to model relationships between top predator foraging ecology metrics and multiple climatic, oceanographic, and ecological indices to identify factors most influential to top predator foraging ecology and consistency across species. As little empirical data exists on the ecological response of marine top predators to long-term environmental change, data generated herein may ultimately aid prediction of responses to future environmental changes and development of risk mitigation strategies.

 

Broader Impacts: In addition to the research objectives, this Fellowship allowed me to engage in a number of outreach initiatives aimed at increasing access to STEM fields and broadening participation of historically excluded groups. Through this research project, I mentored four graduate students and eight undergraduate students in attaining greater proficiency in laboratory practices pertinent to molecular isotope geochemistry, project design, data analysis, and science communication. Four of these students have backgrounds historically excluded in STEM; 10 were women. During my Fellowship tenure, I was a member and co-chair of a college-level Justice, Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion Committee and led the development and implementation of various continuing education trainings related to diversity, equity, inclusion. I also participated in several public outreach events and initiatives (e.g., Science Saturday, Letters to a Pre-Scientist Program, National Ocean Sciences Bowl), developed a publicly available educational video on the topic of food webs, co-organized a conference symposium, and co-organized a Twitter conference. I presented my NSF-funded research at four scientific conferences and two departmental seminars. 

 

Lastly, this Fellowship granted me the opportunity to develop expertise in multiple scientific fields that will be a central focus of my research program into the future (e.g., CSIA-AA, climate change, multiple stressors). I have been able to leverage this new expertise to develop several new collaborations with scientists in academia and governmental and non-governmental organizations studying topics such as multiple stressor-impacts on coral reef food web dynamics, sponge food web dynamics, and endangered species ecology.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2022
Modified by: Matthew D Ramirez
